Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Ethics as an Expert Guided and Socially Situated Activity

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Ethics Education in Science and Engineering award supports a study of ethical decision making in research teams of engineering students, with the aim of improving ethics education for engineering students and ultimately ethical practice among professional engineers. The study focuses on the group dynamics of ethical decision making in project teams and research labs to determine whether the presence of an "ethics expert" acts as an effective resource to improve ethical decision making. Answering this question requires a multidisciplinary approach involving theoretical work in both practical ethics and situated learning as well as qualitative observational research that includes experimental studies of ethical decision making in group projects. The project includes developing a normative philosophical framework for situational, collaborative ethical reflection and problem solving, and applying that framework to ethics training for engineering. Graduate and undergraduate students in engineering are observed in ethical decision making in situ and participate in activities where they consult with "ethics experts" -- students in a special ethics course about ethical and social issues in technology -- about concerns arising in their research projects. Experimental studies compare the behavior and results produced by teams that do and do not interact with the "ethics experts."

The intellectual merits of this research include contributions to the fields of philosophical ethics, moral psychology, pedagogical theory, and science and engineering education. Specifically, this project generates new ideas in ethics about the possibility and role of experts and expertise and the way that responsibility and ethical decision making can be constructed in group situations. This study also investigates a new range of phenomena for moral psychology, which has primarily focused on ethical decision making by individuals rather than on the dynamics of group reflection, decision making, and the social distribution of moral responsibility. The proposal expands the situated learning approach to cases of ethical training and the options for ethics pedagogy, which will generate results that will be the basis of new materials for ethics training in science and engineering education. Results will be widely disseminated via journal publications and open forums on the web. This research will have broader impacts on the current practices of engineering ethics education that emphasize abstract principles, individual responsibility, and case studies of extreme situations. Engineers trained according to this program are expected to more readily use the resources available to them in their professional environments, such as an ethics office or ombudsperson, and to function effectively in team decision making about ethical issues. The researchers plan follow up this project by developing curricular resources to expand this type of training to other programs and institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given the importance of science and technology in our society, engineering plays a major role in many prominent social and environmental issues. In response to such issues, engineering education must move to engage with the social context of engineering and the social responsibilities of engineers. At present, engineering students appear to have relatively narrow and rigid views of professional ethics, especially in their social context. Our study focused on the way that students understand engineering ethics and on whether and how engineering ethics will influence their decision-making in actual research and design processes as part of team activities. These activities simulate the real-world social settings where engineering takes place. We also focused on the potential role of “ethics experts” in mediating the understanding and use of ethics in research and design. The goal of our study was to investigate group dynamics of ethical decision-making in student project teams and research laboratories and to determine whether the presence of ethics experts acts as an effective structure or resource to improve ethical decision-making.

In our four-year study, we observed teams of engineering students in design project settings discussing ethical issues that arose from their actual projects. We also conducted participatory observation in engineering research labs in order to study how engineers discuss and use their understanding of engineering ethics during the research process. The primary methodology in this study was cognitive ethnography. Cognitive ethnography combines traditional ethnographic methods from anthropology and sociology with analytical methods from cognitive science suited to analysis of complex cognitive tasks, for example, tasks of meaning making and knowledge production.

Our study revealed the following important phenomena: 1) There can be a disconnect between engineering students’ explicit and implicit understanding of engineering ethics, as evidenced by explicit decision-making and by subtle verbal and nonverbal cues. 2) That implicit understanding of engineering ethics, in some cases, could provide a valuable resource for improving engineering ethics education. 3) Ethics advisors with a philosophy or humanities background, but no particular competence in engineering, can be brought in to help structure and facilitate ethics discussion, when the relationship between engineers and advisors is set up to create a collaborative environment. 4) Ethics discussions and explicit ethical decision-making is probably extremely rare in the engineering labs. 5) Engineering students and researchers develop a repertoire of methods for avoiding or disengaging from discussion of ethically difficult topics.

Concerning the first two phenomena, student teams demonstrated a multi-layered understanding of engineering ethics: explicit and implicit. Explicitly, student teams demonstrated a strong understanding of responsibility for technical correctness and of practical work ethics, while demonstrating a lack of understanding about social implications and social responsibilities. Unlike student team’s explicit understanding, which was fairly uniform, student teams’ implicit understanding of engineering ethics varied between teams. Sometimes a student team’s implicit understanding of engineering ethics was not consistent with, or was even more broad and engaged than, a team’s explicit understanding. For example some teams indicated in their attitude or choice of words that they recognized their social responsibilities (implicit understanding), but shifted those responsibilities to users in verbal statements (explicit understanding). Student team’s implicit understanding played the role of intuition or insight in ethics discussion, but rarely did it directly influence teams’ final decision-making. We suggest that future research attempt to tap the resources of implicit understanding to create better engagement with the social context of engineering ethics.

Phenomenon (3) was observed in the part of our study where we introduced peer advising to engineering student teams’ ethics discussions. Humanities students volunteered to act as ethics experts to guide decision-makings. The presence of ethical experts helped engineering student teams’ ethical decision-making, but only under the conditions of mutual engagement and collaboration. In our original design, where advisors were given minimal guidance, such conditions did not obtain, and ethical discussions were unproductive. We revised the study design early on to create the conditions of productive discussion. Our published work on this topic can provide a model for ethics advising in engineering education and the engineering workplace.

Concerning (4), we found that voluntary ethics discussions rarely occurred in engineering labs. This poses a problem both for researchers who want to study engineering ethics in naturalistic settings, as well as for any attempt to improve engineering ethics in the lab. Engineers in the research lab were, however, willing to discuss when prompted in certain ways. Related to this issue is phenomenon (5), the common strategies used by engineering students and researchers to disengage from discussion of difficult ethical questions. Our descriptive account of these strategies will hopefully help future researchers and ethics educators determine how to prompt engineers to create ethical engagement.
